fullProgramDescription: The Department of Philosophy at UCLA is one of the largest and most distinguished in the world. The undergraduate major in Philosophy is designed to provide students with a broad understanding of the central areas of philosophy, including metaphysics, epistemology, ethics, logic, and the history of philosophy. The major is structured to allow students to explore various subfields within philosophy and to develop their critical thinking, writing, and analytical skills.
shortProgramDescription: The Philosophy B.A. at UCLA offers a comprehensive education in the fundamental areas of philosophy, preparing students for a wide range of careers or further study.
classHighlights: Students are required to take a series of core courses that introduce them to the main subfields of philosophy, including metaphysics and epistemology, ethics, logic, and the history of philosophy.
The major offers a range of upper-division courses in areas such as metaphysics, ethics, logic, philosophy of mind, philosophy of language, and the history of philosophy.
Students can choose from a variety of electives to explore specific interests and deepen their understanding of philosophical issues and debates.
The major emphasizes the development of critical thinking, writing, and analytical skills, preparing students for a range of careers or further study in philosophy or related fields.
learningOutcomes: Demonstrate a broad understanding of the central areas of philosophy, including metaphysics, epistemology, ethics, logic, and the history of philosophy.
Apply critical thinking, writing, and analytical skills to philosophical issues and debates.
Analyze and evaluate complex philosophical arguments and theories.
Develop and defend their own philosophical positions and arguments.
Understand the historical development of philosophical thought and its relevance to contemporary debates.
creditRequirements: 48 units (upper and lower division) for the major; total 180 quarter units or 120 semester units for the degree
additionalInformation: Students must satisfy the College's residency and unit requirements. The major is flexible, allowing students to pursue various interests within philosophy. Students are encouraged to consult with departmental advisors to plan their course of study.
